newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japanese contractor becomes latest victim of bubble.
newsitem.headline: Japanese contractor becomes latest victim of bubble.

text.p: Japan's troubled construction sector saw its second-biggest post-war failure Friday when a medium-sized contractor sought protection from its creditors after buckling under massive "bubble"-era problem loans.
Tokyo-based Tokai Kogyo Co. Ltd said it filed for court protection from its creditors after abandoning a plan to rebuild its troubled business.
It became the first listed general contractor to go under in Japan's post-war history.
It was the second major failure by a Japanese general contractor in the past four years. Osaka-based Muramoto Construction Co Ltd went under in 1993 with 530 billion yen ($4.69 billion) in debts.

Tokai, listed on the first section of the Tokyo bourse, said it was burdened with debts of 511 billion yen ($4.52 billion). It also tops the list of Japanese builders which have guaranteed huge loans which may not be recoverable.
Tokai's shares were suspended by the Tokyo stock market after they fell on the news and are due to be delisted on Oct. 5.

The news about Tokai renewed market jitters over the fragile health of Japan's construction sector, a major casuality of Japan's bad loan crisis, and prompted sales in shares like Tobishima Corp and Aoki Corp.

Japan's construction firms have been struggling to recover from the collapse of Japan's 1980s "bubble" of sky-high asset prices, which left them heavily encumbered with problem loans. Builders led the bubble-era investment in property and real estate and also guaranteed loans by their real estate units.

The sluggish pace of Japan's economic recovery, coupled with lingering loan woes and a squeeze on public works spending, is putting heavy pressure on builders' earnings and has made any substantial turnarounds doubtful.

Tokai, hit by sluggish property sales and falling land prices, had tried but failed to win necessary financial support from all of its four major banks -- Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd, Tokai Bank Ltd, the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan and Norinchukin Bank.
